results.title: Steam days: Travels with a Duchess and the fishing line
results.creator_credit: Neil Cameron, Peter Walton and BBC
results.brief_description: Presented by Miles Kington, dedicated enthusiast, this celebration of the steam age looks at some of the great British engines, travels the famous lines and meets the wonderfully eccentric people who keep steam alive in Britain today. “Travels with a Duchess” looks at The Duchess of Hamilton, one of the most famous passenger trains built in the 1930s. “The Fishing Line” travels the fishing line from Fort William to Malliag, built to transport herring at the end of the nineteenth century.
results.title_for_label: Steam days: Travels with a Duchess and the fishing line

results.title: Steam days 2
results.creator_credit: Neil Cameron, Peter Walton and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Another delightful program for lovers of steam trains and travel. Two episodes featured. “Workhorses” covers the history of steam freight trains in Britain. Miles Kington reflects fondly on the unsung heroes of the railways. “Going Great Western” takes us on the Great Western Railway, which opened the so-called Cornish Riviera to travellers in the Victorian era. Features beautiful West Country scenery.

results.title: Steam at war: the home front
results.brief_description: Using footage from three classic wartime railway short films- ‘Carrying the Load’, ‘Necessary Journey’ and ‘Southern on Service’, this tape profiles Britain’s railways during the tumultuous Second World War. It covers a gamut of wartime operations, including troop and freight trains carrying men and munitions, Luftwaffe raids on railways, mobile hospital carriages, rail mounted anti-aircraft guns on the Romney, Hythe and Dymchurch narrow-gauge railway, the naming ceremony of the ‘Home Guard’ loco, plus many other memorable moments. Also included on the tape is exclusive footage of the North Yorkshire Moors Railway ‘Steam at War’ weekend. A weekend which is noted for its recreation of the sights and sounds of wartime steam on the home front.

results.title: Staying upfront
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is a film about a long distance owner truck driver and his family. The reasons why he became an owner-driver are explored as well as the rewards he gets from it, and the effect on his family of operating in a high pressure, often marginal income industry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Ramsey, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia

results.title: Status = Status anxiety
results.creator_credit: James Runcie, Neil Crombie and Channel Four Television Corporation
results.brief_description: Alain de Botton presents this three-part documentary series which is an exploration of the modern dilemma of how work and objects define a person’s status in western society. Are we cash rich but spiritually poor? Does wealth equate to happiness? Why do we worry so much about what people think of us? Alain de Botton has a interesting take on this resulting in thought provoking television through the use of contemporary interviews mixed with some views of ancient philosophers brought into the contemporary context. He also talks to people with an alternative view, such as naturists and bohemians, to find out their understanding of ‘status’. Another interesting series by the same presenter is “Philosophy: a guide to happiness” [318970]. Written by Alain de Botton.

results.title: Stations
results.brief_description: A story, set in Brisbane in 1953, about a young woman who falls in love and becomes pregnant. What follows is a painful and deliberate account of women’s resilience in the face of the dilemmas and social constraints of Australia in the fifties. Stars Noni Hazelhurst and Tim Burns.

results.title: Starting from scratch
results.brief_description: An instructional video providing informative and simple advice on gardening techniques for the beginner or even the experienced gardener. Presented by Peter Seabrook, a garden specialist who writes and broadcasts both in the UK and the USA, and Anne Swithinbank, a writer and broadcaster for the BBC with regular appearances on Gardeners’ World, the video is divided into two programs titled “A New garden” and “Renovating a derelict garden”. Each program is dealt with in detailed sections with close-up photography and demonstrations of the techniques used. Also includes a booklet of notes and guidelines.

results.title: Start to Read
results.creator_credit: Tony Wise, Jacky Moini, Thames Television and Video Collection
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learn with Sooty”.
This video explains the importance of knowing how to read, with many examples and exercises which show this to be true. The video will help young children learn at their own individual pace in a way that is both meaningful and enjoyable.

results.title: Stars of the Russian ballet
results.brief_description: Sovexportfilm Australia presents this historic feature length production made in 1953 and beautifully preserved. It is a compilation of three ballets, featuring both world famous Kirov and Bolshoi Ballets. The first of the three ballets is Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” with Galina Ulanova as the beautiful White Swan - Odette, and the outstanding Natalya Dudinskaya as the rivalling Black Swan - Odile. The second ballet is “The Fountains of Bakchisarai” based on the poem by Alexander Pushkin and starring the internationally acclaimed Maya Plisetskaya as the seductive Zarema and Galina Ulanova as the tragic Maria. The final ballet is “The Flames of Paris” the breathtaking tale of the French Revolution, with magnificent sets and costumes and one of the largest casts ever assembled for a ballet.
